sentence-detokenized: EU rejects German call to boycott British lamb.
Peter Blackburn
BRUSSELS 1996-08-22
The European Commission said on Thursday it disagreed with German advice to consumers to avoid British lamb until scientists have established whether mad cow disease can be transmitted to sheep.
Germany's representative on the EU Veterinary Committee Werner Zwingmann said on Wednesday that consumers should buy sheep meat from countries other than Britain until scientific advice is clearer.
"We do not support such a recommendation because we see no reason for it," Commission chief Nikolaus van der Pas told a press conference.
He said further scientific studies were needed and if it was found that action was needed, the EU should take action.

He said a proposal last month by EU Agriculture Commissioner Franz Fischler to ban sheep brains, spleens and spinal cords from the human and animal food chain was a very specific and precautionary step to protect human health.
Mr Fischler proposed action at EU level following reports from the UK and France that sheep can be infected with BSE - mad cow disease - under laboratory conditions.

But Mr Fischler agreed to reconsider his proposal after the EU Standing Veterinary Committee and national animal health officials questioned whether such a measure was justified, given the low risk to human health.
Earlier, at a meeting of EU agriculture ministers, Spanish Agriculture Minister Loyola de Palacio had accused Fischler of creating unfounded unrest through "dangerous generalisations".
Only France and Britain supported Fischler's proposal.
The EU Scientific Veterinary Committee and inter-service committees will review the issue early next month and make recommendations to senior veterinary officials.
Sheep have long been known to contract scrapie, a brain disease similar to BSE, which is thought to have been transmitted to cattle through feed containing animal waste.

British farmers denied on Thursday that their sheep pose any danger to human health, but expressed concern that the German government's advice to consumers to avoid British lamb could affect consumers across Europe.
"We have to be very careful about how other countries will follow Germany's example," John Lloyd Jones, president of the Welsh National Farmers' Union (NFU), told BBC radio.

Bonn has been at the forefront of efforts to protect public health since consumer confidence collapsed in March after a British report suggested people could contract a disease similar to mad cow disease from eating contaminated beef.
Germany imported 47,600 sheep from the UK last year, almost half of the total.
It imported 4,275 tonnes of British sheepmeat, representing about 10% of total imports.
Rare draft of Hendrix song sells for nearly $17,000.
A rare early handwritten draft of a song by American guitar legend Jimi Hendrix sold for nearly $17,000 on Thursday at an auction of some of the late musician's favourite items.
A Florida restaurant paid £10,925 ($16,935) for the draft of "Ain't No Telling," which Hendrix wrote on a piece of stationery in a London hotel in late 1966.
At the end of a concert in January 1967 in the English city of Nottingham, he threw the paper into the audience, where it was picked up by a fan.
The buyers also got 16 other items put up for auction by Hendrix's former girlfriend Kathy Etchingham, who lived with him from 1966 to 1969.
They included a black lacquer and mother-of-pearl inlaid box Hendrix used to store his drugs, which an anonymous Australian buyer bought for £5,060 ($7,845).
The guitarist died of a drug overdose in 1970 at the age of 27.
China says Taiwan is spoiling the atmosphere for talks.
BEIJING 1996-08-22

China on Thursday accused Taipei of spoiling the atmosphere for a resumption of talks across the Taiwan Strait with a visit to Ukraine by Taiwan's Vice President Lien Chan this week that infuriated Beijing.

Just hours after Chinese state media said the time had come to open political talks with Taiwan, Foreign Ministry spokesman Shen Guofang told Reuters, "The atmosphere necessary for the opening of negotiations has been disturbed by the Taiwanese authorities."
State media quoted China's top negotiator with Taipei, Tang Shubei, as telling a visiting group from Taiwan on Wednesday that it was time for the rivals to hold political talks.
"It is now time for the two parties to engage in political negotiations...
that is, to end hostilities," Thursday's overseas edition of People's Daily quoted Tang as saying.

Shen of the Foreign Ministry told Reuters Television in an interview that he had read reports of Tang's comments but gave no details of why the negotiator thought the time was right to hold talks with Taiwan, which Beijing regards as a renegade province.
China, which has long opposed all Taipei's efforts to gain greater international recognition, was infuriated by a visit to Ukraine this week by Taiwan's Vice President Lien.
China says the time has come for negotiations on Taiwan.
BEIJING 1996-08-22
China has said it is time for political talks with Taiwan and that the rival island should take practical steps in that direction.

Consultations should be held to determine the timing and format of the talks, the official Xinhua news agency quoted Tang Shubei, vice president of the Association for Cross-Strait Relations, as saying late Wednesday.
The number of German car registrations in July rose by 14.2 per cent year-on-year.
FRANKFURT 1996-08-22
German first-time registrations of motor vehicles rose 14.2 percent in July this year compared with the same period a year earlier, the German Federal Motor Vehicle Office said Thursday.
According to the office, 356,725 new cars were registered in July 1996 - 304,850 passenger cars and 15,613 trucks.
The figures represent an increase of 13.6 percent for passenger cars and a decrease of 2.2 percent for trucks compared to July 1995.
Motorcycle registrations increased by 32.7 percent over the period.
The growth was partly due to an increased number of Germans buying German cars abroad, while manufacturers said domestic demand was weak, the federal office said.
Almost all German car manufacturers had an increase in registrations during the period.
Volkswagen AG received 77,719 registrations, just over a quarter of the total.
Opel AG came in second with General Motors, with 49,269 registrations, representing 16.4 percent of the total.
In third place came Ford with 35,563 registrations, or 11.7 percent.
Only Seat and Porsche had fewer registrations in July 1996 compared to July last year.
Seat had 3,420 registrations compared to 5,522 registrations in July of the previous year.
The number of Porsche registrations fell to 554 from 643.
GREEK SOCIALISTS GIVE GREEN LIGHT TO PM FOR ELECTIONS.
The Greek Socialist Party's executive committee gave the green light to Prime Minister Costas Simitis to call a snap election, General Secretary Costas Skandalidis told reporters.
Prime Minister Costas Simitis will make an official announcement after a ministerial meeting later Thursday, Skandalidis said.
-- Dimitris Kontogiannis, Athens Newsroom +301 3311812-4

Israel downplays fears of war with Syria.
Colleen Siegel
JERUSALEM 1996-08-22
Israel's outgoing peace negotiator with Syria said Thursday that the current tensions between the two countries appear to be a tempest in a teacup.
Itamar Rabinovich, who as Israel's ambassador to Washington led fruitless negotiations with Syria, told Israel Radio that it seemed Damascus wanted to talk rather than fight.
"It seems to me that the {(1)[MISC] Syrian priority} is still to negotiate.
The Syrians are confused, they're certainly tense, but the general assessment here in Washington is that this is basically a storm in a teacup," he said.
Rabinovich is completing his term as Ambassador.
He will be replaced by Eliahu Ben-Elissar, a former Israeli envoy to Egypt and right-wing politician from the Likud party.
Israel sent a message to Syria via Washington on Wednesday saying it was committed to peace and wanted to start talks without preconditions.
But it criticised Damascus for creating what it called a dangerous atmosphere.
Syria on Wednesday accused Israel of launching a hysterical campaign against it after Israeli television reported that Damascus had recently test-fired a missile.
It said its arms purchases were for defensive purposes.

"The message that we sent to (Syrian President Hafez al-) Assad is that Israel is ready at any time and without preconditions to start peace negotiations," Israeli Foreign Minister David Levy told Israel Radio in an interview.
Tensions have grown since Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu took office in June pledging to preserve the Golan Heights, which Israel captured from Syria in the 1967 Middle East war.
Israeli-Syrian peace talks on the Golan have been deadlocked since 1991, despite the previous government's willingness to make concessions on the Golan.
Peace talks between the two sides were last held in February.
"The voices coming from Damascus are bad, not good.
The media...
are full of expressions and statements that must be worrying...
This artificial atmosphere is very dangerous because those who spread it can become its prisoners," Levy said.
"We expect Syria, if it is committed to peace, to respond to Israel's message to start peace negotiations, because that is our goal," he said. "
We don't want war, God forbid.
No one benefits from wars. "
Israeli TV station Channel Two said Damascus had sent a "reassuring signal" to Israel.
It cited no source for the report.
Netanyahu and Levy spokesmen said they could not confirm that.
The TV station also said Netanyahu had sent messages to Syria to reassure Syria via Cairo, the US and Moscow.
Polish diplomat denies nurses are stranded in Libya.
A Polish diplomat on Thursday denied a Polish tabloid report this week that Libya was denying exit visas to 100 Polish nurses who tried to return home after working in the North African country.
"That's not true.

Until today, we are not aware of any nurse being stranded or detained in Libya without her will and we have not received any complaints," the Polish embassy's charge d'affaires in Tripoli, Tadeusz Awdankiewicz, told Reuters by telephone.

Poland's Labour Ministry said this week it would send a team to Libya to investigate, but Awdankiewicz said the investigation was prompted by some nurses complaining about their working conditions, such as non-payment of wages.
He said there are an estimated 800 Polish nurses working in Libya.
Two Iranian opposition leaders meet in Baghdad.
Hassan Hafidh
BAGHDAD 1996-08-22
An Iranian exile group based in Iraq pledged Thursday to provide support to Iran's Kurdish rebels after they were attacked by Iranian troops deep inside Iraq last month.

A statement from the Mujahideen Khalq says its leader Massoud Rajavi met in Baghdad with the Secretary General of the Kurdistan Democratic Party of Iran (KDPI) Hassan Rastegar on Wednesday and expressed his support for Iran's Kurdish rebels.
"Rajavi stressed that the Iranian resistance will continue to stand side by side with their Kurdish compatriots and the resistance in Iranian Kurdistan," it said.
A spokesman for the group said the meeting "signals a new level of cooperation between the Mujahideen Khalq and the Iranian Kurdish oppositions".
Iran heavily bombed targets in northern Iraq in July in pursuit of KDPI guerrillas based in Iraqi Kurdish areas outside government control in Baghdad.
The Iraqi Kurdish areas bordering Iran are under the control of guerrillas from the Iraqi Kurdish group PUK (Kurdish Patriotic Union of Kurdistan).
The PUK and Iraq's Kurdistan Democratic Party (KDP), the two main Iraqi Kurdish factions, have been in control of northern Iraq since Iraqi forces were driven out of Kuwait in the 1991 Gulf War.
Clashes between the two sides erupted at the weekend in the most serious fighting since the ceasefire agreed last year with US support.
The Mujahideen Khalq said Iranian troops had also shelled KDP positions in the Qasri region of Suleimaniya province near the Iranian border in the past two days.
It said about 100 Iraqi Kurds were killed or wounded in the attack.
Both Iran and Turkey carry out air and ground strikes against targets in northern Iraq in pursuit of their own Kurdish insurgents.
A US-led air force in southern Turkey protects Iraqi Kurds from possible attacks by Baghdad troops.
The Saudi riyal is stable in a quiet summer trade.
The Saudi riyal in the spot market against the dollar and riyal interbank deposit rates were mostly stable this week in quiet summer trading, dealers in the kingdom said.
"There were no changes in the Saudi riyal exchange rates.
The market was very quiet because of the summer holidays," said one dealer.
Spot riyal was set at 3.7504/06 to the dollar.
One-month interbank deposits were at 5-1/2, 3/8 percent, three-month deposits at 5-5/8, 1/2 percent and six-month deposits at 5-3/4, 5/8 percent.
One-year funds stood at six, 5-7/8 percent.
Israel approves Arafat's flight to the West Bank.
JERUSALEM 1996-08-22
Israel on Thursday gave Palestinian President Yasser Arafat permission to fly over its territory to the West Bank, ending a brief crisis between Israel and the PLO, an Arafat adviser said.
"The problem is solved.
The president's plane has been allowed to pass through Israeli airspace, but the president is not expected to travel to the West Bank until Monday," Nabil Abu Rdainah told Reuters.

Arafat was due to meet former Israeli Prime Minister Shimon Peres in Ramallah in the West Bank on Thursday, but the meeting was moved to Gaza after Israel denied Palestinian leaders permission to fly their helicopters.
Palestinian officials accused right-wing Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of trying to stop the Ramallah meeting by keeping Arafat on the ground.
Arafat subsequently cancelled a meeting between Israeli and PLO officials on civilian issues at the Allenby Bridge between Jordan and the West Bank.
Abu Rdainah said Arafat had decided not to fly to the West Bank on Thursday after Israel lifted the ban because he had a busy schedule in Gaza and would not be free until Monday.
Arafat to meet Peres in Gaza after flight ban.
JERUSALEM 1996-08-22

Yasser Arafat will meet Shimon Peres in Gaza on Thursday after Palestinians said the Israeli right-wing government had prevented the Palestinian leader from flying to the West Bank for talks with the former prime minister.

Japan's Finance Minister Wataru Kubo told a news conference Wednesday that he believes the Bank of Japan's (BOJ) interest rate policy, aimed at ensuring economic growth, has not changed following the publication of the central bank's "tankan" survey.
